phrase.item: Whether it is true or not, there was once an orphan (boy)
His parents were dead, he lived with his grandmother. He said to his grandmother: "Grandmother, either we die [of hunger],
or I will go steal."
He then went to steal from the royal treasury.
He stole all of the royal treasure.
There was nothing left in the treasury.
The king searched hard, [but] could not find the thief.
The king had a camel
that devoured everything
When people or birds came, this camel eats them in flight.
One night the king released his camel.
When orphan came, he saw the camel was loose.
He started running and the camel started chasing after him.
The orphan ran away and reached the door of his house.
He had an apricot tree and he jumped up it.
The camel made it there too; [the orphan] grabbed its yoke and tied it to the apricot tree.
He went to get a knife and cut off [the camel's] head.
That night he skinned it.
He took the meat and put it in his dairy.
He brought water and washed outside, he cleaned up the blood.
The king saw in the morning that the camel was not there.
He called all the people in the city and told them: "Whoever finds my camel, I will give that person all my wealth."
An old woman went to the city and began to search.
She went from house to house saying: "My grandson is sick and needs camel's-liver medicine."
She couldn't find any anywhere.
She came to the orphan's house and said to his grandmother: "My grandson is sick, do you have any camel's liver?"
The old woman said: "I don't."
Then she thought and said: "Well, I have a little."
She took from the camel's liver and leaves the house.
At the door she encountered the orphan.
He said: "Grandmother, where were you?"
She said: "Child, my grandson is sick and camel's liver is the treatment."
"I couldn't find anywhere, but I found it in your house."
The orphan told her: "Grandmother, a camel's liver is not medicine, its head is."
Give me the liver and I will give you the head; I have a niche, and through that niche you must pass it three times and I will pass it three times--
then you can take it and go.
The old woman rejoiced
She went immediately and started to give
Twice the old woman gave it to him amd twice he gave it back.
The third time he held the old woman by the hand, took a knife, and cut off her arm at the elbow
The old woman started to cry.
She marked the door with her blood.
That night she went and told the king.
The orphan took her hand and rubbed all the doors in the city.
The next day dawned.
The king got up and walked with the old woman, the old woman led him.
The king saw that every door in the city was covered in blood.
They arrived at the orphan's house.
Right away the orphan fetched a donkey's ornamental dress and put it around his neck, and he and his grandmother got inside the oven.
ɣəf=typo?
He rubbed ash on his and his grandmother's head.
The king entered and the old woman said: "Here is your robber."
"me"?
: The king said: "A curse on your father!"
They could not get down from the oven.
How could they slaughter my camel?
He used to eat birds out of the air!
He became angry and left.
He went and sat in his own house.
He thought a lot.
Then his daughter said: "Father, make me provisions for a journey and I will find your thief."
Her father made her provisions for the journey and she set off.
"gox" for "goç" a typo?
She came to a desert and pitched her tent as night fell.
xajma(j)=?
The ophan thought for a while and said: "Well, a goat is made to be killed; now if I go with the king's daughter I will put a high price (?), but whatever happpens happens."
He made a skin and filled it with water, took the old women's hand to his bosom and left.
"taɣdə" a typo for "taʝdə"?
He approached the king's daughter
and slept with her.
In the morning he said: "O daughter of the king, I am going outside."
She said: "Unfortunate orphan, you slept with me, you did wrong and now you are planing to run away."
He said: "No, I will not run."
"Hold my hand while I urinate."
He slipped her the old woman's hand, pierced the [water]skin with an awl, and ran.
It started splashing.
The sun rose.
The king's daughter forced herself saying: "The sun has risen, what are you doing?"
She looked up and saw that the orphan had gone.
She stood up, disgraced, took the hand and came to her father house
She said: "Father, I have found your thief."
Since last evening we were fighting till morning, I pulled his hand and it came off.
The king rejoiced, saying: "Now I will find my robber, who is missing a hand."
Then the old woman stood up and said: "O king, that is hand is mine."
The king became furious.
They tied the old woman to a horse's tail and set the stallion loose.
They tore the old woman apart. But the king, the citizens, the vizier, and the village elder all remained in a state of consternation. [More from French than from Wakhi]
"tlim-tlim"?
The king's daughter had become visibly pregnant.
She gave birth to a son.
The son grew up.
The minister and the village elder said: "O king, except this boy himself there is no one who knows his father".
So he gave an order, saying: "However many men there are in this city, bring them all [here]."
They brought all the inhabitants of the city
Including the orphan.
The orphan thought: "Now the boy will recognize me."
So he left, and on the way he found a snake.
He took it to his breast and entered into the house.
He sat next to the single piller.
They brought in the boy
and put him down on the floor.
what's "jortʃ"
He walked around and came towards the orphan's side
[The orphan] revealed the snake's head
The boy screamed and ran back.
They returned him (the boy) [to the floor.]
The orphan thought: "Hey, male goat." The boy went to him and climbed onto his lap.
The French text says the orphan thought "Well, what must be can't be avoided, after all he is my son!" rather than "Hey, male goat"
He embraced him.
The inhabitants of the city were surprised.
He said: "O king, it was also I who robbed your treasure, slaughtered your camel, and violated your daughter."
This son is mine.
Now the choice is yours.
At that moment the door opened; the king of another city had sent a letter to disgrace the king.
He had written: "O king, a curse on your father! what kind of king are you that your treasure has been stolen--or were you not aware?"
"Your camel was killed, were you not aware?"
"Finally, your daughter was violated, were you not aware?"
The king read this and was paralyzed with shame.
"ʃirminda"?
Then the orphan also stood up and said: "O king, do you have any goats whose hair trails on the ground?"
The king said: "I do."
He said: "Bring and slaughter it, I will make [that king] ashamed before you."
"ʃirminda" again
Immediately the king slaughtered it.
And hung a bell from each hair.
The king made a trunk.
The orphan took the trunk and left on a camel [named] Wind.
Or maybe "on a fast camel." The French has it both ways: "on a fast camel named Wind"
He put on the skin
That night, he got up and left.
At midnight he reached the [other] king's place, got off the camel, and at the gate he shook himself saying: "Oh, guards open the door!"
"If you open it it is good; if you don't open it, [know that] I am Azrael and I will pull out your soul.
The guards were frightened, opened the door immediately, and sat far away
He shook himself and, rattling and ringing, entered that night the king's castle, where the king and his wife were sleeping.
He was fast asleep.
He shook himself there saying: "O king, get up--it is I, Azrael, and I will take your soul."
The king woke up and said: "O Azrael, don't take my soul until I have made my ablutions and recited my prayer. Then you can take my soul."
He said: "No, I won't take your soul away but on one condition: you and your wife get into this trunk naked."
"I will close the trunk's lid, and knock there."
"You must crow like a rooster and your wife cluck like a hen, then I will spare your soul."
Right away the king and his wife, naked, got into the trunk.
He [the orphan] closed the trunk's lid.
He picked up the trunk and left.
He put it on the camel, Wind, and early in the morning reached the door of the [first] king.
When he arrived, all the people of the city were waiting
Then he called the king: "Come closer, king!"
The king came close.
He knocked on the top [of the trunk].
The king [inside] crowed like a rooster and his wife clucked like a hen.
He [the orphan] then opened the lid.
The king greeted him, saying: "O king, have you seen my thief?"
The king then said from the inside: "O king, cursed be the father of a king who disgraces another king."
"I am ashamed before you, do not shame me before [all these] people."
He closed the lid right away.
The orphan took them to their city and returned. The king married his daughter to the orphan according to the Muslim rite and gave the orphan his throne and fortune.
God willing, the same will happen to you.
